journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering

title-group.article-title: A simple parametric identification procedure based on the final value theorem

contrib-group.aff: Department of Automatic Control, University of Niš, Serbia

author-notes.corresp: Milica B Naumović, Department of Automatic Control, Faculty of Electronic Engineering, University of Niš, Aleksandra Medvedeva 14, 18000 Niš, Serbia. Email: milica.naumovic@elfak.ni.ac.rs

abstract.p: The present paper describes the application of the final value theorem of the Laplace transform in the identification procedure of a continuous-time parametric model. The presented identification approach involves only a number of integrating processes and is suitable for easy automation. Three examples are used to demonstrate the effectiveness and merits of the considered identification algorithm.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: An important step in process control is the identification of a ‘suitable’ model of a continuous-time system from real observations.1,2 What suitable means depends primarily on the concrete application one has in mind. Thus, it is necessary to select an appropriate level of model complexity depending on the purpose of system identification. Moreover, the acceptance of models should be guided by ‘usefulness’ rather than by ‘truth’. Many identification methods discuss the parameter estimation problems both of continuous-time and discrete-time system models. A detailed overview of such methods is given in Ljung.3 Least-squares, step response and frequency response methods are representative as deterministic offline identification approaches. The system identification techniques based on the continuous-time model were initiated in the middle of the last century,4 but for some time were overshadowed by the overwhelming developments in discrete-time methods. This was mainly due to the ‘go completely digitally’ trend that was the result of the parallel development in digital computers.

The present paper studies a deterministic offline identification method of the rational transfer function which can be performed by using the data of a constant steady-state output step response. Such identification methodology, known as transient response analysis, is simple to apply and understand, and often provides information only good enough for the estimates of the input–output gain, the dominant time constants, as well as the time delays. These properties make the method suitable for the first stage of the analysis to prepare for the other experiments in the system identification.

The paper is organized as follows. Before the simple identification method is presented, some preliminary facts are introduced. The properties of the identification procedure are summarized and illustrated by several simulation results. Finally, some conclusions of the work are presented.

sec.title: Parametric identification method
sec.p: In this section, some assumptions are made for the plant to be identified, and an identification approach is considered.
A single-input single-output linear dynamical system can be described by a time-invariant linear differential equation

where u(t) and c(t) denote the input and output of the system, t represents the time variable, and c(i)(t)=defdic(t)/dti, u(i)(t)=defdiu(t)/dti. Coefficients ai and bi are the parameters of the system. Under the zero initial values, taking the Laplace transform to both sides of equation (1) and using the differential property, we can obtain
where C(s) and U(s)are the Laplace transforms of c(t) and u(t). Hence, we have the proper rational transfer function of the control system type-0
Assume that u(t) is a step function with the amplitude U0. Starting from the unit step response
by using the final value theorem of the Laplace transform
the coefficients of the model transfer function

can be determined. The final value theorem is an extremely handy result in Laplace transform theory. Recall that the standard assumption for the final value theorem requires that the Laplace transform of the signal C(s) has all poles in the left-half of the s-plane, except possibly at most one pole at the origin. A special expanding in the context of the theorem generalization to irrational functions is given in Chen et al.5

Note that the method is based on the area determination and the graphical interpretation of the first step of the algorithm is shown in Figure 1. According to the final value theorem of the Laplace theorem, we have

Table 1 contains a summary of the identification procedure in the case when all bj parameters except b0 in equation (3) are equal to zero.

caption.p: Algorithm for computing the parameters of the transfer function in equation (3).

sec.p: Figure 2 presents a simple block diagram for performing all calculations in the described identification procedure. The measured data, obtained experimentally from a real-time set-up, can be used in the MATLAB®/Simulink environment to identify unknown system parameters. It is obvious that the considered identification approach is very simple and can be realized with the minimal computational effort.7 The method is more difficult to implement if the model to be identified is given in the form of the transfer function with finite zeros.

caption.p: Schematic diagram of the considered identification procedure.

sec.title: Simulation examples
sec.p: In this paper, the described method is illustrated by three examples related to the fourth-order linear objects without finite zeros, and one real control object.

sec.title: Example 1
sec.p: Consider the fourth-order linear system described by the following differential equation

In simulation, the input is taken as a step signal with amplitude equal to 10. The important point is that the duration of the simulation should be sufficient to ensure that the input signal is able to excite the slowest system mode. The estimated parameters for a fourth-order model are shown in Figure 3 (left plot). It can be seen that after 25 s the estimated parameters converge to the true values. The right plot of Figure 3 visualizes the migration with time of two pairs of the complex conjugate poles of the estimated transfer function in the s-plane towards the exact locations. The locations (i), (ii) and (iii) correspond to the moments of 1 s, 10 s and 30 s, respectively.

caption.p: Left plot: estimated model parameters in Example 1. Right plot: migration of the estimated transfer function poles versus time.

sec.title: Example 2
sec.p: Figure 4 visualizes one of the various configurations to be obtained with the ECP Model 210 Rectilinear Plant by using springs of varying stiffness.8 A drive motor provides actuation to the system via the first mass, and position measurements xi(t), i=1,2 are taken by quadrature encoders.

caption.p: Schematic diagram of the electro-mechanical plant.

sec.p: The equations for the considered mass–spring system may be found using Newton’s laws to write force balance equations in matrix notation as
where
The parameters of this set-up can be found in the literature8 as follows: m1=1.7kg, m2=1.2kg, k1=k2=800N/m, k3=450N/m and c2=9Ns/m. The above motion equation results in the transfer function
which can be equivalently rewritten in such a way as in equation (1), with

It should be noted that all ai parameters have low values, and moreover are of different order of magnitude, which is the known characteristic of electro-mechanical systems. For the purpose of the fourth-order model parameter estimation, the algorithm described in the previous section was applied. Table 2 presents estimated values of the a and b parameters obtained at some different conditions of experimentation. The results illustrate some of the fundamental identification problems of the considered system related to the experiment duration and the accuracy of data presentation.

Thus, the electro-mechanical plant given in Figure 4 can be adequately represented by the fourth-order model obtained after the identification procedure lasting 20 s and retaining the larger number of decimal places corresponding to the MATLAB data presentation in long format.

sec.title: Example 3
sec.p: Experimental evaluation of the identification approach has been performed for a direct current (DC) motor that is part of an experimental environment presented in Naumović.9 An incremental encoder is used for the position measurement with a resolution of 210lines/revolution.

Note that the output signal, i.e. the measured position of the motor shaft, does not have a finite limit, and the considered identification approach cannot be directly applied. In order to get the system type-0 that can be identified, the motor shaft speed, estimated by using the well-known Euler’s approximation of the derivative (the first difference estimator), is adopted as the output signal. Due to the finite resolution of the angle measurement, the shaft speed signal would be highly contaminated by the quantization noise. In order to improve the quality of the shaft velocity signal, the commonly used Butterworth low-pass filter is implemented. Although higher-order Butterworth filters contribute a significant amount of time lag, for the purpose of identification, the idea of a simple shifting of the filtered velocity signal to the left along the time axis proved to be useful.

The top plot of Figure 5 compares the results obtained by using the first difference velocity estimator, before (solid line) and after (dashed line) filtering by using an eighth-order Butterworth filter. The time-shifted version of the filtered shaft velocity signal is indicated by the dotted line. The shaft speed signal would be highly contaminated by the quantization noise, as can be better seen on the enlarged scale of part of the same responses (insert, top plot, Figure 5). The bottom plot of Figure 5 serves to verify the results of the identification process. The actual shaft position (dashed line) and the estimated DC motor model output (solid line) are plotted. Better agreement can be achieved in the case with some other choice of the filter structure and its parameters, but the filtering process was not the subject of this paper.

caption.p: Responses in Example 3. Top plot: shaft speed derived by the first difference estimator (solid line), low-pass filtered speed signal (dashed line) and time-shifted version of the filtered signal (dotted line). Bottom plot: comparison of identified model output (solid line) and measured shaft position (dashed line).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: System identification is a well-established field. However, the search for simple procedures of identification is still a special scientific challenge. This paper presents an identification algorithm implemented in the MATLAB/Simulink environment based on the final value theorem, which is a well-known result in the Laplace transform theory. The identification approach is very simple and requires minimum computational effort. The presented parametric identification approach is an offline procedure suitable in engineering education.

The properties of the described identification method are illustrated by some simulation runs within three examples. The quality of the estimation scheme is analysed in the case of the noise-corrupted system step response. Experimental application to a motor drive system yields a good matching of the estimated model output and actual system output.
